page.title: 17Sunderland Point/Fishing
page.content: The Lune Estuary is a source of small scale commercial fishing. Wild migrating salmon and sea trout are netted under licence by ancient methods. Whammeling or drift netting from small open boats on the ebb tide and haaf netting, standing in the edge of the estuary with a beam mounted net are the usual methods. Trawling for shrimps and fixed nets for whitebait complete the commercial netting; timber baulks and other fixed nets having declined. Full-time fishermen are almost extinct at Sunderland; within living memory fishing was the main occupation. Sunderland Point is a pilot station for the Lune. The ships trade in grain, coal, scrap metal, and other cargoes between the continent or the Isle of Man and Glasson Dock.
